Summary I am interested in the behavior of biological macromolecules, specifically RNA. There has been an explosion in the discovery of functional and non-coding RNA molecules, as well as sophisticated systems (such as RNAi/CRISPR) to regulate the lifetimes and functions of these molecules. My project in Dan Herschlag's lab is to create a predictive model for how these RNA molecules fold to form intricate 3-dimensional shapes in order to function. This model is based on the energetics of individual parts of the molecules that can be 'added' together to predictive the stability of different conformations of the RNA.  
 
I am also very interested in how the kinetic behaviors of enzymes has implications for in vivo function, specifically related to the Argonaute and Cas9 proteins. Experience Graduate Student Stanford University 2009  – Present (6 years) Graduate student in Daniel Herschlag's lab in the Biochemistry Department at Stanford. I primarily do single-molecule studies of RNA folding and nucleic acid biochemistry, with some computational work on macromolecule conformation prediction. Goal of project is a thermodynamic and kinetic dissection of RNA folding steps in order to build up a predictive understanding of more complex RNAs from the behavior of its component parts. Teacher ADC, Cairo November 2008  –  January 2009  (3 months) Taught English to middle-class Cairenes. I developed lesson plans and conversation topics to stimulate dialogue between very different cultural groups. Undergraduate Reseacher Princeton University 2006  –  2008  (2 years) In the lab of Coleen Murphy, I studied the physiological effects of aging in mutant and WT C.elegans. I adapted a large scale imaging platform to take movies of thousands of worms through their duration of their lifespan in order to identify biomarkers of aging, the timescale of responses for aging worms, and the objective comparison of lifespans of WT and aging mutant worms. Summary My expertise lies in the area of machine learning, computer vision and sensors. I have developed successful research programs as well as groups in industry and startups for several applications. 
 
I have created and led several efforts to translate machine learning techniques for end-to-end products. These include startups I co-founded, zunavision, Cognical Zibby and Holopad, as well as R&D groups in companies such as Sony Ericsson, IBM and some DARPA/IARPA projects. 
 
In academic circles, I started with machine learning during my PhD at Stanford with Prof. Andrew Ng, where I had developed end-to-end algorithms and systems for computer vision and robotics applications, such as making 3D model from a single still image and a robot that unloads items from a dishwasher (which made it to the frontpage of NY Times). At Cornell, I ran a research group of about 20 people working on developing new machine learning algorithms for Robots. Now I am back at Stanford, continuing my efforts in the form of Robo Brain project (http://robobrain.me). See an informal article about it in the Wired magazine: http://www.wired.com/2014/08/robobrain/ 
 
My academic efforts have been recognized as awards for research papers, fellowships and Career awards to me and to my PhD students, as well as in the popular press. Our robots have been featured in prime time national news and TV, including BBC, NBC, FOX News, and even Comedy Central. Director, Robo Brain project.  
RoboBrain is a large-scale knowledge engine that learns from millions of sources on the Internet, such as Wikipedia, WikiHow, YouTube, and also from several robots (cars, mobile manipulators,...) in four research institutions: Stanford, Cornell, Brown and Berkeley. RoboBrain as-a-service has allowed several robots to share knowledge for performing their tasks efficiently.

Experience Director of Data Science Lumos Labs (Lumosity) December 2014  – Present (9 months) San Francisco Bay Area Leading a small team of data scientists focused on generating insights from Lumosity's cognitive performance data, optimizing the cognitive training experience for effectiveness and achieving users' goals, and building tools for internal analysis efforts. Senior Data Scientist Lumos Labs (Lumosity) January 2012  –  December 2014  (3 years) san francisco bay area At Lumosity, my data science practice involves using my background in cognitive psychology and data analysis to deliver scientific, product and business insights. 
 
My work includes: 
 
Analyzing our database relating cognitive game performance data to learning differences, aging, geographic location and other variables. My work has been presented at academic conferences, featured in numerous media outlets as well as in peer-reviewed journals like Frontiers in Human Neurosciences. 
 
Evangelizing our data and research to others. I've given talks at SXSWEdu, SharpBrains Virtual Summit and spoken to numerous media outlets. 
 
Work with product engineering teams to deploy new features using our data: 
- Designed new training system algorithm used to create daily workouts, at the heart of Lumosity's daily training experience. 
- Redesigned overall scoring system (LPI) that is used throughout the site to allow users to track their progress, understand their strengths and weaknesses, and compare themselves to others.  
 
Work with marketing, product and Data Engineering teams as statistical consultant: 
- Developed simple statistical tools and dashboards to allow easy analysis of multi-arm split tests, most recently via Shiny dashboards. 
- Developed new lifetime value model of individual subscriptions in collaboration with data engineering team. Responsible for initial development and testing of model based on direct payment transaction data. Summary In the course of my PhD research, I was able to develop various nanocharacterization techniques to analyze key structural aspects of magnetic recording media. I hope to apply and modify these techniques to study other nanostructural materials systems in an interdisciplinary field, such as one involving graphene- and spintronics-based devices. 
 
My expertise lies with characterization of device structures at the nanoscale: During my PhD research, I analysed magnetic nanoparticles chemical and physical properties for their utilization in computer memory devices using techniques employing the TEM, SEM, SPM, and XPS. I used high resolution electron microscopy to show the structutal agreement of two polycrystalline thin films in a multilayer device. I was able to show the true amorphous atomic structure of the intergranular phase (IP) in the magnetic layer of these devices. We revealed atomic structural features within the IP of critical effects on the device performance quality factors. These results ultimately help in producing the hard disk drives with increased data storage densities. The work resulting from analyzing the samples was regularly communicated with Western Digital Corp., the funding source of my work, and some were submitted for publication. I was the top student during the masters program and acted as teaching assistant in various classes offered in the department. During summer sessions, I trained undergraduate students conduct research and produce reports from their work in my field of expertise who are now in their PhD programs at top universities.
